Context:
Program Name: Interior Design
Code: T178
Credential: Ontario College Advanced Diploma
Duration: 3 years (6 semesters)
Starting Months: January, September
Domestic Tuition: $4,288.00
International Tuition: $17,820.00
Method of Study: Full-time
Centre: Construction & Engineering Technologies
School: Architectural Studies
Location: Casa Loma Campus
Experiential Learning: Co-op available in 3rd year
Delivery: Semester 1, 3: On Campus, Winter 2024: Semesters 1, 2, 4, 6: On Campus.
Program Description: A design isn’t finished until someone is using it. Prepares students to be a valuable member of the design team for interior additions and renovations, leasehold improvements and new construction. Contributing to the technical design of building interiors by developing 2D and 3D presentation and construction drawings incorporating knowledge of building code, sustainability, accessibility, lighting, textiles, furniture, colour and ergonomics.
Program Availability: Fall 2023 - Closed, Winter 2024 - Closed, Spring 2024 - Not Available.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Interior Design Program T178 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
The text provides information about a college program in Interior Design Technology. The program focuses on the development of plans, elevations, renderings, and 3D models in state-of-the-art interior design studios using up-to-date equipment and software. Graduates will gain knowledge in interior design and technical skills, with potential areas of specialization including bathroom and kitchen design/build, commercial, retail or manufacturing technical sales, fitments, color or texture finishes selection and consultations, 2D and 3D computer drawing, design, rendering and modeling, and sustainable interior design practices.

Graduates will have the opportunity to work as junior interior designers, technical representatives for building/equipment suppliers, specification writers, project coordinators, design and color consultants for builders and retail outlets, staging for real estate and film industry, and may be legally able to design interiors of buildings with experience and a Building Code Identification Number.

Career options include junior interior designer, technical positions in builders, architectural and interior design firms, and sales and marketing roles. Graduates may also transfer with advanced standing into the second year of the Architectural Technology program (T109). The text does not provide any factual information about years, numbers, emails, or names.

Context:
The text provides information about a transfer program in Architectural Technology (T109) at George Brown College. Successful graduates of this program can receive a dual advanced diploma and may be eligible for advanced standing in the Honours Bachelor of Technology (Construction Management) degree program.

Required courses for the Architectural Technology program are as follows:

Semester 1:
- ARCH 1005: Architectural Technology & Studio 1
- ARCH 1014: Canadian Industry Practices
- ARCH 1048: Structural Systems 1
- ARCH 1050: Visual Communications 1
- ARCH 1060: Design Fundamentals
- CADE 1012: CAD Drawing 1
- COMM 2000: Communicating Across Contexts
- MATH 1139: Mathematics for Arch/IDT 1

Semester 2:
- ARCH 1006: Architectural Technology & Studio 2
- ARCH 1013: Building Code And Regulations 1
- ARCH 1070: Materials, Methods And Components 1
- ARCH 1109: Building Systems – Mechanical and Electrical
- CADE 1014: CAD Drawing 2
- MATH 1149: Mathematics for Arch/IDT 2
- GNED: General Education Elective

Semester 3:
- ARCH 1109: Building Systems – Mechanical & Electrical
- ARCH 2009: Practice Management
- CADE 2032: Digital Practices For Interiors 1
- COMM 1113: Professional Communications For Building Technologies
- DSGN 1103: History Of Western Design
- DSGN 2001: Interior Design Practices 1
- DSGN 2006: Building Code For Interior Design
- DSGN 2007: Interior Design Studio 1
- GNED: General Education Elective

Semester 4:
- ARCH 2033: Visual Communications 2
- CADE 2042: Digital Practices for Interior Design 2
- DSGN 2011: Interior Design Practices 2
- DSGN 2012: Lighting And Acoustics
- DSGN 2015: Working Drawings & Materials 1
- DSGN 2017: Interior Design Studio 2
- GNED: General Education Elective

Semester 5:
- ARCH 3012: Concentrations In Computational Design 1
- CADE 3042: Digital Practices For Interior 3
- DSGN 3001: Interior Design Practices 3
- DSGN 3009: New Technologies in Interior Design
- DSGN 3017: Interior Design Studio 3
- DSGN 3024: (Not listed)

Students must take General Education Elective courses in each semester. For more information about transferring and advanced standing, visit the Diploma to Degree page on George Brown College's website.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Interior Design Program T178 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
The text provides information about various courses offered in Interior Design, Architecture, Computational Design, Digital Practices for Interior Design, and Communication under Semester 6 at the college. These include DSGN 3017, 3024, 3025, ARCH 3018, 3026, 3032, CADE 3014, and DSGN 3008. The students may need to take COMM 1000 before progressing to COMM 2000 based on their placement test results. General Education Electives are also mentioned.

The graduates from the program are expected to adhere to building and accessibility codes, produce accurate construction drawings with specifications, employ principles of sustainability, develop design solutions considering various factors, communicate design ideas effectively, manage time and budgets, use professional communication practices, and employ ethical business practices.

Program Learning Outcomes:
1. Adhere to building and accessibility codes, regulations, standards and practices that protect the health, safety and welfare of the public.
2. Produce accurate construction and detailed drawings with accompanying specifications to fully convey the design proposal.
3. Employ principles of sustainability in the specification of new and conventional materials, equipment and technologies to create objects, interiors and assemblies.
4. Develop design solutions considering the use of space, the physical environment, accessibility needs, and preferences to meet client needs.
5. Employ the principles and elements of design, and the relationship between form and function to create the design solution.
6. Communicate design ideas, concepts, and trends for various projects, reflecting the use of theory and contemporary practice in the design solution.
7. Develop plans for design objects and space using appropriate volumetric manipulation conventions and technologies to create design solutions.
8. Effectively manage time, budgets, and workloads to achieve the desired design solution.
9. Employ business ethics and professional practices in all design work for establishing and maintaining organizational and practitioner reputation.
10. Employ verbal, written, visual and digital communication skills to formally present well-articulated design proposals and solutions to a client, and/or other involved parties.
11. Employ professional communication practices in interaction, negotiation and collaboration with coworkers, consultants, contractors, clients.

There is no specific key information related to the name or contact details of the college from the text.

Context:
The text provides information about communication practices expected of students, design evaluation criteria, tuition and fees for domestic and international students, financial assistance, admission requirements, and mature student options.

1. Communication practices: Employ professional communication practices in interaction, negotiation, and collaboration with various groups.
2. Design Evaluation: Evaluate designs based on concept, appropriateness, effectiveness, sustainability, codes and regulations, accessibility, user experience, and cost.
3. Tuition & Fees:
   - Domestic tuition for the first two semesters of programs starting in Fall 2022: $4,288.00
   - International tuition for the first two semesters of programs starting in Fall 2023: $17,820.00
   - Fees are subject to change for programs starting in Fall 2024 and at later dates.
4. Financial Assistance: This program is approved for OSAP funding if the applicant meets OSAP eligibility criteria.
5. Admission Requirements:
   - Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent
   - Grade 12 English (C or U)
   - Grade 11 math (M or U) or grade 12 (C or U)
   - Mature students may take the Admissions Assessment for English and math or upgrade to achieve required credits.
6. Course Exemptions: College or university credits may qualify for course exemptions.
7. International Students: Visit the International Fees and Related Costs page for more information.
8. Disclaimer: Information is subject to change without notice. Students should verify George Brown College fee requirements.

Context:
For applying to George Brown College:
1. Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges.
2. International students should apply through the George Brown College Online Application System.
3. Contact the School of Architectural Studies at 416-415-5000, ext. 4365 or email architecturalstudies@georgebrown.ca for information. Their office hours are from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m., room D303.
4. International students can contact recruitment representatives specializing by country of origin through the International Contact Us page.
5. Visit the campus for an information session and sign up at Sign up for an information session.
6. Related programs offered: Architectural Technology (T109), Architectural Technician (T132), Graphic Design (G102).
7. Sign up to receive tailored resources for application.

Contact Information:
- George Brown College Contact Centre: 416-415-2000, TTY 1-877-515-5559, or long distance 1-800-265-2002.
- International recruitment representatives can be contacted through the International Contact Us page.

Programs Offered: Architectural Technology (T109), Architectural Technician (T132), Graphic Design (G102).
